thread.title: Border Force Melbourne visa check operation cancelled amid protests
thread.title_full: Border Force Melbourne visa check operation cancelled amid protests | afr.com

author: Post to Linkedin
title: Border Force Melbourne visa check operation cancelled amid protests
text:
Demonstrators protest against Border Force Joe Armao As well as the Border Force officers and the Victoria Police, staff from Metro Trains, Yarra Trams, the Sheriff's Office and Taxi Services Commission were also to be part of the activity.
In the statement the Border Force warned Melburnians they would need to know their own visa status.
"ABF officers will be positioned at various locations around the CBD speaking with any individual we cross paths with," the Border Force's Victoria and Tasmania regional commander, Don Smith, said.
"You need to be aware of the conditions of your visa. If you commit visa fraud you should know it's only a matter of time before you're caught out."
 Protesters have taken to the streets of Melbourne after the federal government announced the Australian Border Force will this weekend target potential visa fraudsters in the heart of the city. Joe Armao After an overwhelming response on social media, the Immigration and Border Protection department then issued new statements and social media posts saying it would not just be stopping people at random.
"To be clear, the ABF does not and will not stop people at random in the streets...The ABF does not target on the basis of race, religion or ethnicity," the spokesperson said.
In one of these social media posts, the Border Force said their officers would check the visas of those referred to them.
"ABF officers will assist partner agencies by conducting background visa checks on individuals who are referred to us," a ABF tweet said.
Andrew Wilkie: The Govt has stopped this due to public outrage not because they think it is wrong #auspol #BorderForce #OperationFortitude
â€” ABC News 24 (@ABCNews24) August 28, 2015 With a press conference slated for 2pm at Flinders Street Station, a snap protest was organised and chaos ensued, with the surrounding streets swapped by over 200 people.
Sensing the furor, Victorian Police cancelled the conference, and then cancelled the entire operation.
"Victoria Police has made a decision not to go ahead with this weekend's Operation Fortitude.
"We understand there has been a high level of community interest and concern which has been taken into consideration when making this decision," they said in a statement.
The Victorian Government have since hit out at the Department of Immigration and Border Protection saying it was an "unfortunate and inappropriate characterisation" of a "standard police operation".
"Operation Fortitude was intended to be a standard police operation.
"We fully support the decision by Victoria Police to cancel the operation after the unfortunate and inappropriate characterisation by the Australian Border Force today," they said.
Labor have said the announcement and cancellation was "shambolic".
"This has been incredibly badly handled and Peter Dutton needs to immediately come clean on how this announcement was so botched
"Mr Dutton needs to immediately explain to the community what on earth has transpired. Who sanctioned this announcement being made, what was its purpose, who called for its retraction and who is responsible for compromising this operation?" Labor's Immigration and Border Protection spokesperson, Richard Marles, said.
Immigration and Border Protection Minister, Peter Dutton, was asked to comment on the handling of the operation by his department.
A spokesman for the minister said it was an operational matter, and the minister did not direct operations.
